titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Burgoyne Diller Collection of Printed Material, 1932-1961, in the Archives of American Art
titlestmt.author: by Jean Fitzgerald

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Christina Lehman on June 10, 2005

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

did.unittitle: Burgoyne Diller collection of printed material
did.abstract: Burgoyne Diller's collection of printed material measures 0.2 linear feet and dates from 1932 to 1961. The collection primarily documents Diller's career through printed material consisting of clippings and exhibition announcements and catalogs. There is also one letter from the James Gallery dated 1959.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Born in New York City in 1906, Burgoyne Diller was brought up in Michigan. He returned to New York in 1926 and studied at the Art Students League from 1928 to 1932. With Hans Hofmann, Diller made his first geometrical paintings in the 1930s, embracing the rigid formulas of Piet Mondrian's "pure plastic art," which included the use of horizontal and vertical lines as well as primary colors. Diller became director of the Mural Division of the New York City Works Progress Administration, Federal Art Project in 1935, and remained in government service until 1941. In 1945, he became associate professor of art at Brooklyn College. Burgoyne Diller died in 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection measures 0.2 linear feet, dates from 1932-1961, and includes one letter, clippings, and exhibition announcements and catalogs that concern the development of Burgoyne Diller's unique artistic style.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 2 series:

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed in the online catalog of the Archives of American Art under the following index terms. People, families and organizations are listed under "Subjects" when they are the topic of collection contents and under "Names" when they are creators or contributors.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in 1982 by Morris Dorsky, chairman of the Brooklyn College Art Department. Diller taught at Brooklyn College from 1946-1963. Presumably the materials were compiled either by Diller, or by someone in the Art Department.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research. Use requires an appointment and is limited to the Washington, D.C. research facility.

userestrict.head: Ownership and Literary Rights
userestrict.p: The Burgoyne Diller collection of printed material is owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Burgoyne Diller collection of printed material, 1932-1961. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Jean Fitzgerald in October 2002.

did.unittitle: Letter from Lillian Orlowsky of the James Gallery, 1959
